instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN:
What is PCH_INTVRMEN? PCH_INTVRMEN is an Internal Voltage Regulator Enable: When pulled high, this signal enables
the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must
remain asserted for the VRMs to behave properly (no glitches allowed).
This signal must be pulled-up to VCCRTC on desktop platforms and may
optionally be pulled low on mobile platforms if using an external VR for the
VCCSUS rail.
definitions.ALL_SYS: What is ALL_SYS? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYS, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.PP3V4_G3H: What is PP3V4_G3H? This is a typo of PP3V3_G3H When you see PP3V4_G3H, assume they meant to type PP3V3_G3H.
definitions.U5000: What is U5000? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in macbooks from 2013-2015.
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD: What is SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD? SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a pre-requisite for SYS_PWROK_R and PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK..
definitions.SMC_TPAD_RST_L: What is SMC_TPAD_RST_L? SMC_TPAD_RST_L is a signal that comes from the trackpad that can reset the SMC when it is low.  _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v. The trackpad having corrosion from liquid damage is a very common cause of no light on the magsafe charger & the system not turning on, when the trackpad or trackpad cable is corroded and holding this line down. .
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.S5_PWR_EN: What is S5_PWR_EN? S5_PWR_EN is a signal that turns on all S5 power rails when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC: What is PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC? PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC Is a reference voltage for the SMC’s voltage sensors & other sensors..
definitions.PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA: What is PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA? PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state that powers the SMC that comes from PP3V3_S5. A blown or corroded L4901 inductor behind it can kepe it from working, inductor number will differ depending on your board. .
definitions.SMC_TCK: What is SMC_TCK? SMC_TCK is a signal that must be pulled up to 3.42v in order for the SMC to be in the proper mode to function. Often this is not pulled up because of corrosion or corroded resistors by the SMC. .
definitions.SMC_TDI: What is SMC_TDI? SMC_TDI is a signal that must be pulled up to 3.42v in order for the SMC to be in the proper mode to function. Often this is not pulled up because of corrosion or corroded resistors by the SMC. .
definitions.SMC_TMS: What is SMC_TMS? SMC_TMS is a signal that must be pulled up to 3.42v in order for the SMC to be in the proper mode to function. Often this is not pulled up because of corrosion or corroded resistors by the SMC. .
definitions.SMC_TDO: What is SMC_TDO? SMC_TDO is a signal that must be pulled up to 3.42v in order for the SMC to be in the proper mode to function. Often this is not pulled up because of corrosion or corroded resistors by the SMC. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF: What is SMC_ONOFF? SMC_ONOFF is a signal that tells the machine that the power button has been pressed so it knows to turn on, or turn off. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> sem energia
threads.message:
Good morning, this Mac suffered oxidation, the components <RESISTOR>R5198</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R5230</RESISTOR>, and <CHIP>U5870</CHIP> had oxidation, replace them, but without results. 


Voltage:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> =12.63V
<SIGNAL>PP3V4_G3H</SIGNAL>= 3.42V
<SIGNAL>SMC_REST_L</SIGNAL>= 3.34V 
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>= 0V, no pulse 
  <SIGNAL>3_S5</SIGNAL> / SUS = 0V, no pulse 
<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 0v, no pulse 
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> = 3.29V
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> = 3.42V
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> = 0.04V, no pulse
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> = 0V, no pulse 

<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> =3.04V
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL>= 3.27V
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> = 0v, pulseless
<SIGNAL>RTC_REST_L</SIGNAL> =3.42V

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> =0V, no pulse.
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> =3.42V

Note: I am using 85W charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> sem energia
threads.message:
Did you solder correct value for <RESISTOR>R5198</RESISTOR>?
Do you get <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>?

Check voltages and signals for <CHIP>U5000</CHIP> (2 OF 2), at page 37.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> sem energia
threads.message:
No idea where did you find all these on block (2 OF 2).

Post now basic voltages for <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>; pins 23, 12, 13, 22, 29, 21.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> sem energia

Sorry, I informed the wrong board model in the post, I already corrected it.
23 3.31
12 0v
13 0V
22 3.31V
29 0V 
21 4.6V

There MUST be <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> sem energia
threads.message:
It replaces the SMC, without result.
When I activate <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL>, the MagSafe light turns green.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> sem energia
threads.message:
Magsafe light MUST be always green, if no battery connected.
Light should not react when pressing power button.
If reacts in your case, check <SIGNAL>SMC_TPAD_RST_L</SIGNAL>; MUST be steady high.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> sem energia
threads.message: <SIGNAL>SMC_TPAD_RST_L</SIGNAL> 3.3V, it is always high, until when it triggers <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> sem energia
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_TPAD_RST_L</SIGNAL> shouldn't be affected by <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.
Unless <CHIP>U4850</CHIP> is incorrectly triggered at same time.
Disconnect keyboard and test using <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16 pads, instead of power button.
